com.twitter.heron.streamlet

Interface KVStreamlet<K,V>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    BaseStreamlet<KVStreamlet<K,V>>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    JoinStreamlet, KVConsumerStreamlet, KVFilterStreamlet, KVFlatMapStreamlet, KVIdentityMapStreamlet, KVLogStreamlet, KVMapStreamlet, KVRemapStreamlet, KVSinkStreamlet, KVStreamletImpl, KVTransformStreamlet, KVUnionStreamlet, MapToKVStreamlet, ReduceByKeyAndWindowStreamlet, ReduceByWindowStreamlet, SourceKVStreamlet, SupplierKVStreamlet

    @InterfaceStability.Evolving
public interface KVStreamlet<K,V>
extends BaseStreamlet<KVStreamlet<K,V>>
    Some transformations like join and reduce assume a certain structure of the tuples that it is processing. These transformations act on tuples of type KeyValue that have an identifiable Key and Value components. Thus a KVStreamlet is just a special kind of Streamlet.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      java.util.List<KVStreamlet<K,V>> clone(int numClones)
      Clones the current Streamlet.
      void consume(SerializableConsumer<? super KeyValue<? super K,? super V>> consumer)
      Applies the consumer function to every element of the stream This function does not return anything.
      KVStreamlet<K,V> filter(SerializablePredicate<? super KeyValue<? super K,? super V>> filterFn)
      Return a new Streamlet by applying the filterFn on each element of this streamlet and including only those elements that satisfy the filterFn
      <K1,V1> KVStreamlet<K1,V1> flatMap(SerializableFunction<? super KeyValue<? super K,? super V>,? extends java.lang.Iterable<KeyValue<? extends K1,? extends V1>>> flatMapFn)
      Return a new Streamlet by applying flatMapFn to each element of this Streamlet and flattening the result
      <V2,VR> KVStreamlet<KeyedWindow<K>,VR> join(KVStreamlet<K,V2> other, WindowConfig windowCfg, JoinType joinType, SerializableBiFunction<? super V,? super V2,? extends VR> joinFunction)
      Return a new KVStreamlet by joining 'this streamlet with ‘other’ streamlet.
      <V2,VR> KVStreamlet<KeyedWindow<K>,VR> join(KVStreamlet<K,V2> other, WindowConfig windowCfg, SerializableBiFunction<? super V,? super V2,? extends VR> joinFunction)
      Return a new KVStreamlet by inner joining 'this streamlet with ‘other’ streamlet.
      void log()
      Logs every element of the streamlet using String.valueOf function This is one of the sink functions in the sense that this operation returns void
      <K1,V1> KVStreamlet<K1,V1> map(SerializableFunction<? super KeyValue<? super K,? super V>,? extends KeyValue<? extends K1,? extends V1>> mapFn)
      Return a new KVStreamlet by applying mapFn to each element of this KVStreamlet
      <R> Streamlet<R> mapToStreamlet(SerializableFunction<? super KeyValue<? super K,? super V>,? extends R> mapFn)
      Return a new Streamlet by applying mapFn to each element of this KVStreamlet
      KVStreamlet<KeyedWindow<K>,V> reduceByKeyAndWindow(WindowConfig windowCfg, SerializableBinaryOperator<V> reduceFn)
      Return a new Streamlet in which for each time_window, all elements are belonging to the same key are reduced using the BinaryOperator and the result is emitted.
      KVStreamlet<K,V> repartition(int numPartitions)
      Same as filter(filterFn).setNumPartitions(nPartitions) where filterFn is identity

      Applies the sink's put function to every element of the stream This function does not return anything.

      Returns a new Streamlet by applying the transformFunction on each element of this streamlet.
      KVStreamlet<K,V> union(KVStreamlet<? extends K,? extends V> other)

      • clone

        java.util.List<KVStreamlet<K,V>> clone(int numClones)
        Clones the current Streamlet. It returns an array of numClones Streamlets where each Streamlet contains all the tuples of the current Streamlet
        Parameters:
        numClones - The number of clones to clone

      • union

        KVStreamlet<K,V> union(KVStreamlet<? extends K,? extends V> other)
        Returns a new Streamlet thats the union of this and the ‘other’ streamlet. Essentially the new streamlet will contain tuples belonging to both Streamlets

      • transform

        <K1,V1> KVStreamlet<K1,V1> transform(SerializableTransformer<? super KeyValue<? super K,? super V>,? extends KeyValue<? extends K1,? extends V1>> serializableTransformer)
        Returns a new Streamlet by applying the transformFunction on each element of this streamlet. Before starting to cycle the transformFunction over the Streamlet, the open function is called. This allows the transform Function to do any kind of initialization/loading, etc.
        Parameters:
        serializableTransformer - The transformation function to be applied
        Returns:
        Streamlet containing the output of the transformFunction

      • log

        void log()
        Logs every element of the streamlet using String.valueOf function This is one of the sink functions in the sense that this operation returns void

      • consume

        void consume(SerializableConsumer<? super KeyValue<? super K,? super V>> consumer)
        Applies the consumer function to every element of the stream This function does not return anything.
        Parameters:
        consumer - The user supplied consumer function that is invoked for each element of this streamlet.

      • toSink

        void toSink(Sink<? super KeyValue<? super K,? super V>> sink)
        Applies the sink's put function to every element of the stream This function does not return anything.
        Parameters:
        sink - The Sink whose put method consumes each element of this streamlet.

      • join

        <V2,VR> KVStreamlet<KeyedWindow<K>,VR> join(KVStreamlet<K,V2> other,
                                            WindowConfig windowCfg,
                                            SerializableBiFunction<? super V,? super V2,? extends VR> joinFunction)
        Return a new KVStreamlet by inner joining 'this streamlet with ‘other’ streamlet. The join is done over elements accumulated over a time window defined by TimeWindow.
        Parameters:
        other - The Streamlet that we are joining with.
        windowCfg - This is a specification of what kind of windowing strategy you like to have. Typical windowing strategies are sliding windows and tumbling windows
        joinFunction - The join function that needs to be applied

      • join

        <V2,VR> KVStreamlet<KeyedWindow<K>,VR> join(KVStreamlet<K,V2> other,
                                            WindowConfig windowCfg,
                                            JoinType joinType,
                                            SerializableBiFunction<? super V,? super V2,? extends VR> joinFunction)
        Return a new KVStreamlet by joining 'this streamlet with ‘other’ streamlet. The type of joining is declared by the joinType parameter. Types of joins JoinType The join is done over elements accumulated over a time window defined by TimeWindow.
        Parameters:
        other - The Streamlet that we are joining with.
        windowCfg - This is a specification of what kind of windowing strategy you like to have. Typical windowing strategies are sliding windows and tumbling windows
        joinType - Type of Join. Options JoinType
        joinFunction - The join function that needs to be applied

      • reduceByKeyAndWindow

        KVStreamlet<KeyedWindow<K>,V> reduceByKeyAndWindow(WindowConfig windowCfg,
                                                   SerializableBinaryOperator<V> reduceFn)
        Return a new Streamlet in which for each time_window, all elements are belonging to the same key are reduced using the BinaryOperator and the result is emitted.
        Parameters:
        windowCfg - This is a specification of what kind of windowing strategy you like to have. Typical windowing strategies are sliding windows and tumbling windows
        reduceFn - The reduce function that you want to apply to all the values of a key.
